paragraphs.text:
%md
# About

**Lab:** Configuring HDFS Centralized Cache
**Objective:** Create, list, modify, and remove a Cache Pool and a Cache Directive
**File Locations:** N/A
**Successful Outcome:** A Cache Pool with two CacheDirectives will be created, modified, and removed. 
**Before You Begin:** Start and connect to your classroom lab environment.

msg.data:
About

Lab: Configuring HDFS Centralized Cache
Objective: Create, list, modify, and remove a Cache Pool and a Cache Directive
File Locations: N/A
Successful Outcome: A Cache Pool with two CacheDirectives will be created, modified, and removed.
Before You Begin: Start and connect to your classroom lab environment.

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Setup

%md
# Lab

%md
### Prepare the lab environment

paragraphs.title: 1 - Add a new Linux user to the node
paragraphs.text:
%md
*** !!! Skipped first step of "Log in to any cluster node". !!! ***

Add a new Linux user to the node. Use your first name as the new user's name.

%sh
useradd -m <your_first_name>

paragraphs.title: 2 - Create a new HDFS home directory
paragraphs.text:
%md
Create a new HDFS home directory for the new Linux user.

%sh
su - hdfs
hdfs dfs -mkdir /user/<your_first_name>

paragraphs.title: 3 - Populate the directory with files
paragraphs.text:
%md
Copy two files to the new HDFS home directory and then change the ownership of the directory and the files to the new user. Only the size, but not the content of the files, is important for this lab. Then verify that the files were copied, renamed, and the file ownerships are correct.

%sh
hdfs dfs -put /etc/group /user/<your_first_name>/lookuptable
hdfs dfs -put /etc/hosts /user/<your_first_name>/jointable
hdfs dfs -chown -R <your_first_name>:<your_first_name> /user/<your_first_name>
hdfs dfs -ls /user/<your_first_name>

paragraphs.title: 4 - Return to normal root user privileges
paragraphs.text:
%sh
exit

%md
### Configure the maximum amount of per-DataNode memory that can be used by HDFS caching.

msg.data: Configure the maximum amount of per-DataNode memory that can be used by HDFS caching.

paragraphs.title: 5 - Limit how much memory can be locked
paragraphs.text:
%md
In the open terminal window as the root user, use the ulimit command to determine how much memory the Linux operating system has reserved for locked memory.

Remember that the number displayed is the number of kilobytes.

%sh
ulimit -l
# the number "one" or the letter "l"?

paragraphs.title: 6 - Log in to the Ambari Web UI
paragraphs.text:
%md
Open the browser and connect to the [Ambari Server](http://<Ambari Server Hostname>:8080) at the URL.
*** !!! Link to Ambari Server needs to be configured !!! ***

Log in to the Ambari Web UI using the user name `admin` and the password `Bad?Pass#1`.

paragraphs.title: 7 - Add a property to HDFS
paragraphs.text:
%md
Browse to **Services** > **HDFS** > **Configs** > **Advanced**.

*** !!! Image needed here !!! ***

Scroll down and expand **Custom hdfs-site**. Then click **Add Property**.

paragraphs.title: 8 - Configure the locked memory property for HDFS
paragraphs.text:
%md
In the Add Property window, add the `dfs.datanode.max.locked.memory` property. Assign it a value slightly less than the 64 kilobyte `ulimit -l` value seen earlier. For example, use the value `65500`.

This will be sufficient memory for the limited amount of caching used in this lab exercise. Then click Add.

*** !!! Image needed here !!! ***

Click **Save** to save the configuration change.

paragraphs.title: 9 - Save the configuration change
paragraphs.text:
%md
In the Save Configuration window, enter optional notes and click **Save**.

*** !!! Image needed here !!! ***

Then click **OK**.

paragraphs.title: 10 - Restart HDFS
paragraphs.text:
%md
Restart HDFS and any other needed services as indicated in the Ambari Web UI.

*** !!! Image here !!! ***

%md
### Create a Cache Pool that is writeable for a single user account

msg.data: Create a Cache Pool that is writeable for a single user account

paragraphs.title: 11 - Create a new cache pool
paragraphs.text:
%md
Create a new Cache Pool that is owned and writeable by a normal user and only readable by everyone else. The Cache Pool should be limited to 65500 cached bytes and enforce a maximum time-to-live value of 24 hours.

%sh
hdfs cacheadmin -addPool <your_first_name>Pool -owner <your_first_name> -mode 644 -limit 65500 -maxTtl 24h

%md
Did the command succeed? It should not have.
What was the reported problem?

paragraphs.title: 12 - Assume HDFS superuser privileges and try again
paragraphs.text:
%md
Repeat the previous step again, but first assume HDFS superuser privileges.

%sh
su - hdfs
hdfs cacheadmin -addPool <your_first_name>Pool -owner <your_first_name> -mode 644 -limit 65500 -maxTtl 24h

%md
Did the command work this time? It should have.

paragraphs.title: 13 - List current cache pools
paragraphs.text:
%md
List all existing Cache Pools.

%sh
hdfs cacheadmin -listPools

paragraphs.title: 14 - Display the current usage information of the cache pool
paragraphs.text:
%md
List only the one existing Cache Pool and add the option that includes current usage information in the output.

%sh
hdfs cacheadmin -listPools <your_first_name>Pool -stats

%md
Why are the values for BYTES_NEEDED and FILES_NEEDED zero?

paragraphs.title: 15 - Modify the cache pool's max time to live
paragraphs.text:
%md
Modify the Cache Pool's maximum time to live to five days. Then verify the change.

%sh
hdfs cacheadmin -modifyPool <your_first_name>Pool -maxTtl 5d
hdfs cacheadmin -listPools <your_first_name>Pool

paragraphs.title: 16 - Resume normal root user priveleges
paragraphs.text:
%md
Resume normal root user privileges.

%sh
exit

%md
### Add Cache Directives to the new Cache Pool

msg.data: Add Cache Directives to the new Cache Pool

paragraphs.title: 17 - Add the lookuptable cache directive to your pool
paragraphs.text:
%md
Use a Cache Directive to add (cache) the HDFS file /user/<your_first_name>/lookuptable to the <your_first_name>Pool.

%sh
hdfs cacheadmin -addDirective -path /user/<your_first_name>/lookuptable -pool <your_first_name>Pool

%md
Did the command succeed? It should not have.
What was the reported problem?

paragraphs.title: 18 - Assume normal user privileges and try agian
paragraphs.text:
%md
Repeat the previous step again, but first assume the normal <your_first_name> user's privileges.

%sh
su - <your_first_name>
hdfs cacheadmin -addDirective -path /user/<your_first_name>/lookuptable -pool <your_first_name>Pool

%md
Did the command succeed? It should have.

paragraphs.title: 19 - List the cache directives of your pool
paragraphs.text:
%md
List the Cache Directives in your only Cache Pool.

%sh
hdfs cacheadmin -listDirectives -pool <your_first_name>Pool

%md
Was any usage information reported in the output? There should not be any usage information.
What is the time-to-live value? 
How far is that in the future (use the date command to print the current date and time)?
Why is the time-to-live set to this date and time?

paragraphs.title: 20 - Display the usage information of your pool
paragraphs.text:
%md
Repeat the previous command but add the option that includes usage information in the output.

%sh
hdfs cacheadmin -listDirectives -pool <your_first_name>Pool -stats

%md
What are the values of BYTES_CACHED and FILES_CACHED?
If the values are zero, why?
What do you do to "fix" these values so they are non-zero?

paragraphs.title: 21 - Display the usage information of your pool
paragraphs.text:
%md
List the usage information for your only Cache Pool.

*** !!! Repeated step? No instruction to list usage information as superuser !!! ***
*** !!! shell command doesn't include `-stats` flag !!! ***

%sh
hdfs cacheadmin -listPools  <your_first_name>Pool

%md
Did the command work for the normal user? It should have.
Why did the command work for the normal user?
Does the Cache Pool usage information match the Cache Directive's usage information? It should.

paragraphs.title: 22 - Add the jointable cache directive to your pool
paragraphs.text:
%md
Use a Cache Directive to add (cache) the HDFS file /user/<your_first_name>/jointable to the <your_first_name>Pool. Then verify that the command succeeded.

%sh
hdfs cacheadmin -addDirective -path /user/<your_first_name>/jointable -pool <your_first_name>Pool
hdfs cacheadmin -listDirectives -pool <your_first_name>Pool

%md
Did the command succeed?
*It should have.*

What is the replication factor for the `jointable` file?
What is the directive's ID number? Remember it.

paragraphs.title: 23 - Change the replication factor of a cached file
paragraphs.text:
%md
Change the replication factor of the cached `jointable` file to two. Then verify the change.

%sh
hdfs cacheadmin -modifyDirective -id <directiveID> -replication 2
hdfs cacheadmin -listDirectives -pool <your_first_name>Pool

%md
Has the replication factor changed? It should have.

paragraphs.title: 24 - Resume normal root user privileges
paragraphs.text:
%md
Resume normal root user privileges.

%sh
exit

%md
### Remove a Cache Directive

paragraphs.title: 25 - List the cache directives in your pool
paragraphs.text:
%md
a.	As the root user, list the Cache Directives in the <your_first_name>Pool.

%sh
hdfs cacheadmin -listDirectives -pool <your_first_name>Pool

%md
Did the command succeed? It should have.

paragraphs.title: 26 - Remove a cache directive
paragraphs.text:
%md
Remove the Cache Directive for the `jointable` file using the Directive's path.

%sh
hdfs cacheadmin -removeDirectives -path /user/<your_first_name>/jointable

%md
Did the command succeed? It should not.
What problem was indicated by the error message?

paragraphs.title: 27 - Assume privileges of the owner of the file and try again
paragraphs.text:
%md
Repeat the previous command but this time assume the Cache Directives owner's privileges first.

%sh
su - <your_first_name>
hdfs cacheadmin -removeDirectives -path /user/<your_first_name>/jointable

%md
Did the command succeed? It should have.

%md
### Remove a Cache Pool

paragraphs.title: 28 - As a normal user, remove the cache pool
paragraphs.text:
%md
As the <your_first_name> user, remove the Cache Pool.

%sh
hdfs cacheadmin -removePool <your_first_name>Pool

%md
Did the command succeed? It should not have.
What problem was indicated by the error message?

paragraphs.title: 29 - Assume superuser privileges
paragraphs.text:
%md
Assume the HDFS superuser privileges.

%sh
exit
su - hdfs

paragraphs.title: 30 - List the cache directives
paragraphs.text:
%md
How many Cache Directives remain in the Cache Pool?

%sh
hdfs cacheadmin -listDirectives -pool <your_first_name>Pool

paragraphs.title: 31 - Remove the cache pool
paragraphs.text:
%md
Remove the Cache Pool.

%sh
hdfs cacheadmin -removePool <your_first_name>Pool

%md
Was the Cache Pool removed even though it contained a Cache Directive? It should have been.

paragraphs.title: 32 - Assume normal root user privileges
paragraphs.text:
%md
Assume normal root user privileges again.

%sh
exit

%md
# Result

**You have now:** A Cache Pool with two Cache Directives was added to the system. The Cache Pool and Cache Directive were modified. A Cache Directive and the Cache Pool were removed.
